title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: comprehensive checklist preparing submitting R packages CRAN, based ThinkR‚Äôs CRAN preparation guide best practices R community. Key principle: CRAN maintainers volunteers (can counted one hand). Thorough pre-submission validation respects time increases acceptance rates.

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Start Phase 1: Pre-Release Preparation Phase 2: Local Validation Phase 3: Cross-Platform Testing Phase 4: Final Review Phase 5: Submission Post-Submission Common Rejection Reasons Helpful Resources Note Function Syntax: Development functions auto-loaded .Rprofile start R package directory. can call directly (e.g., dev_check_complete()) without using source(). ‚Äôve disabled .Rprofile, use source("dev/function_name.R") instead.

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Timing requirements: - [ ] 30-day minimum CRAN releases (unless fixing critical bugs) - [ ] planned features complete tested - [ ] bugs previous version addressed - [ ] Breaking changes documented NEWS.md First-time submissions: - [ ] Expect longer review times (1-2 weeks vs 1-3 days updates) - [ ] extra thorough - first impressions matter - [ ] cran-comments.md ready explain package

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Update version number DESCRIPTION Major.Minor.Patch (e.g., 1.0.0, 1.1.0, 1.0.1) Remove .9000 development suffix Follow semantic versioning Update NEWS.md changes
code: # Script: Manual editing required # Group changes by: New features, Bug fixes, Breaking changes, Deprecations

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Critical formatting (CRAN strict !): Use Title Case period end Remove ‚ÄúR‚Äù ‚ÄúR‚Äù (redundant CRAN) Max ~65 characters Example: Title: Fast Data Processing Large Datasets Multiple complete sentences elaboration ‚Äúpackage‚Ä¶‚Äù opening package name first word Capitalize software/package names correctly Use parentheses function names: function() Quote external packages correct casing: 'shiny', 'ggplot2' Example: contributors listed correct roles least one cre (maintainer) valid email Include cph (copyright holder) applicable Roles: aut (author), cre (maintainer), ctb (contributor), cph (copyright holder) Valid CRAN license (MIT, GPL-3, etc.) MIT: ensure LICENSE file exists Use HTTPS exclusively (HTTP) Format URLs angle brackets Description: <https://...> Canonical CRAN package links: https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=pkgname Example: used packages listed Imports Suggests unnecessary dependencies Minimum R version specified using recent features Consider using attachment package: attachment::att_amend_desc()
code: Description: Provides efficient algorithms for processing large datasets.     Implements parallel computing techniques to reduce computation time.     Includes visualization tools for exploring results. URL: https://github.com/username/pkgname, https://username.github.io/pkgname/ BugReports: https://github.com/username/pkgname/issues

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Run spell check Add technical terms inst/WORDLIST (one per line) Package names quotes match exact casing typos titles, descriptions, documentation Function documentation completeness Every exported function @return tag (required!) @param tags descriptions empty documentation fields Internal functions use #' @noRd partially documented Check : checkhelper::find_missing_tags() (package installed) Examples quality examples run successfully Replace \dontrun{} (interactive()) {} interactive-code Use \donttest{} slow examples (>5 seconds) Examples demonstrate typical use cases Avoid examples requiring external resources (APIs, databases) Vignettes/Articles (present): code chunks execute without errors absolute file paths references local files Build successfully:
code: test_spelling() # Or directly: spelling::spell_check_package() build_vignettes()

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Run local checks Good practice analysis Code coverage (aim >80%) Test suite File system hygiene Never write user‚Äôs home directory package installation directory Write temporary directories: tempfile() tempdir() Clean temporary files examples/tests Example:
code: dev_check_complete() # Must return: 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes dev_best_practices() # Review and address recommendations test_coverage_report() # Or: covr::package_coverage() test_run() # All tests must pass # Good tmp <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") write.csv(data, tmp) unlink(tmp)  # Bad write.csv(data, "output.csv")  # Don't write to working directory!

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Go systematically: Package passes local R CMD check: 0 | 0 | 0 Windows check passed macOS check passed URLs validated working Spell check passed (0 errors) NEWS.md updated changes Version number incremented tests passing Examples run without errors (quickly) \dontrun{} without good reason DESCRIPTION file formatted correctly function documentation complete (@return tags!) writing user directories (tempdir()) Code committed version control

code: usethis::use_cran_comments() ## R CMD check results  0 errors | 0 warnings | 0 notes  ## Test environments  - Local: Ubuntu 22.04, R 4.3.2 - Win-builder: R-devel (2024-01-15) - Mac builder: R 4.3.1 - R-hub: 20 platforms (all passed)  ## Reverse dependencies  There are currently no reverse dependencies for this package. build_readme() # Or: devtools::build_readme() build_website() # Or: pkgdown::build_site()

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Learn others‚Äô mistakes:

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Problem: Improper formatting Problem: URLs angle brackets Problem: Package names quoted correctly
code: # Bad Title: An R Package for Data Analysis. Description: This package analyzes data.  # Good Title: Fast Data Analysis Tools Description: Provides efficient algorithms for analyzing large datasets.     Implements parallel computing techniques to reduce computation time. # Bad (in Description field) See https://example.com for details.  # Good See <https://example.com> for details. # Bad Uses the Shiny framework...  # Good Uses the 'shiny' framework...

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Problem: Missing @return tags Problem: Overuse \dontrun{}
code: # Bad #' Calculate mean #' @param x numeric vector foo <- function(x) mean(x)  # Good #' Calculate mean #' @param x numeric vector #' @return The arithmetic mean of x foo <- function(x) mean(x) # Bad #' @examples #' \dontrun{ #'   foo(1:10) #' }  # Good #' @examples #' foo(1:10) #' #' # For interactive-only code: #' if (interactive()) { #'   foo(1:10) #' }

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Problem: Writing user directories
code: # Bad - will be rejected! write.csv(data, "~/output.csv") write.csv(data, "output.csv")  # Good - write to temporary directory tmp <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") write.csv(data, tmp) # ... use file ... unlink(tmp)  # Clean up

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Problem: Submitting warnings/notes - Solution: Must 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes (documented acceptable notes) Problem: Examples take long - Solution: Use \donttest{} slow examples, keep 5 seconds possible

title: CRAN Submission Checklist
text: Problem: Submitting updates frequently - Solution: Wait minimum 30 days versions (unless critical bug fix) - Exception: Resubmissions requested changes exempt

code: # Bad http://example.com  # HTTP instead of HTTPS http://dead-link.com  # Broken link  # Good https://example.com  # HTTPS # Run urlchecker::url_check() to verify all links

title: neanderthal
text: neanderthal dataset contains presence pseudo-absence records Neanderthal archaeological sites Marine Isotope Stage 5e (Last Interglacial, ~130,000-115,000 years ago), combined 25 paleoclimate topographic predictor variables. dataset sourced Benito et al.¬†(2017) built support binary classification, species distribution modelling, habitat suitability analysis.

title: neanderthal
text: code loads R libraries example data required run tutorial.

title: neanderthal
text: dataset sf data frame 227 rows 27 columns, missing data. response presence (see neanderthal_response), integer binary variable indicating Neanderthal presence (1) pseudo-absence (0): dataset includes 25 palaeoclimatic (last interglacial) topographic predictors. palaeoclimatic predictors described .

title: neanderthal
text: example shows use neanderthal model Neanderthal habitat suitability Last Interglacial using GAM models. divided following sections: Multicollinearity Filtering: selects non-collinear predictors. Modelling Rationale: explains modelling choices. Model Fitting: fits ensemble univariate GAM models plots response curves. Model Evaluation: computes partial AUC scores univariate models global AUC score weighted ensemble. Habitat Suitability Map: predicts ensemble raster predictors build target map.

title: neanderthal
text: function collinear::collinear() selects non-redundant subset relevant predictors. function ranks predictors AUC univariate binomial GAM models case weights, applies multicollinearity filtering preserves important ones. ranking predictors computed colliinear::collinear() dataset shown . column score shows AUC score univariate model. function selected following predictors:
code: selection <- collinear::collinear(   df = neanderthal,   responses = neanderthal_response,   predictors = neanderthal_predictors,   f = collinear::f_binomial_gam,     quiet = TRUE ) DT::datatable(selection$presence$preference_order[, c("response", "predictor", "score")]) selection$presence$selection #> [1] "bio17"          "bio1"           "bio7"           "bio8"           #> [5] "topo_slope"     "bio13"          "topo_diversity" "topo_wetness"   #> [9] "topo_aspect"    #> attr(,"validated") #> [1] TRUE

title: neanderthal
text: section fit weighted ensemble quasibinomial GAM models case weights. Let‚Äôs unpack ! Case weights: neanderthal dataframe 49 178 absences, imbalance might result overprediction zeros. mitigate issue, function collinear::case_weights() generates inverse-frequency weights classes contribute equally model fit. Quasibinomial GAM: GAM models replace linear terms used GLMs smoothing splines (s()) better represent non-linear relationships presence environment. use quasibinomial family accounts overdispersion introduced pseudo-absence data case weights. basis dimension set k = floor(n_presences/4) capture unimodal monotonic responses expected niche theory keeping smooth well within budget allowed number presences. Combined REML = TRUE select = TRUE, actual complexity penalized , uninformative terms can shrunk zero. Weighted Ensemble: neanderthal data 49 presences. Fitting model predictors might lead overparameterization overfitting. avoid potential issue, fit univariate GAM models presence environmental predictor, ensemble predictions via weighted average, using models‚Äô AUC scores weights.
code: sample_weights <- collinear::case_weights(x = neanderthal$presence) table(sample_weights) #> sample_weights #> 0.00280898876404494  0.0102040816326531  #>                 178                  49

title: neanderthal
text: code fits ensemble univariate GAM models. following plots show predicted probability Neanderthal presence univariate GAM model. Rug marks along x-axis indicate observed data values.
code: models <- lapply(   X = selection$presence$selection,   FUN = function(x){          mgcv::gam(       formula = as.formula(         paste0(           "presence ~ s(",            x, ",            k = ",            floor(sum(neanderthal$presence)/10),            ")"           )         ),       data = sf::st_drop_geometry(neanderthal),       family = stats::quasibinomial(link = "logit"),       weights = sample_weights,       REML = TRUE,       select = TRUE     )        } )  names(models) <- selection$presence$selection response_plots <- lapply(names(models), function(var) {    #extract individual univariate model   model <- models[[var]]   df <- sf::st_drop_geometry(neanderthal)    #prediction grid   newdata <- data.frame(     x = seq(       from = min(df[[var]]),        to = max(df[[var]]),        length.out = 200)     )   names(newdata) <- var    #predict on link scale with standard errors   pred <- predict(     object = model,     newdata = newdata,      type = "link",      se.fit = TRUE     )    #back-transform to probability scale with 95% CI   newdata$fit <- stats::plogis(pred$fit)   newdata$lower <- stats::plogis(pred$fit - 1.96 * pred$se.fit)   newdata$upper <- stats::plogis(pred$fit + 1.96 * pred$se.fit)    #plot response curve   ggplot(newdata, aes(x = .data[[var]])) +     geom_ribbon(       aes(ymin = lower, ymax = upper),       fill = "gray50",       alpha = 0.25     ) +     geom_line(       aes(y = fit),       color = "red4",       linewidth = 0.8     ) +     geom_rug(       data = df[df$presence == 1, ],       aes(x = .data[[var]]),       sides = "t",       color = "red4",       alpha = 0.3,       length = unit(0.1, "npc")     ) +     geom_rug(       data = df[df$presence == 0, ],       aes(x = .data[[var]]),       sides = "b",       color = "gray50",       alpha = 0.3,       length = unit(0.05, "npc")     ) +     scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 1)) +     labs(x = var, y = "P(presence)") +     theme_minimal(base_size = 11) })  patchwork::wrap_plots(response_plots, ncol = 2)

title: neanderthal
text: section compute partial AUC scores univariate model, global AUC ensemble. honest cross-validation evaluation work better , left simplicity. partial AUC scores used weights building ensemble. scores computed via collinear::score_auc(), function able compute AUC . compute intrinsic AUC model, first generate predictions univariate GAM models, average predictions weighted partial AUC scores, finally compare observations. global AUC score indicates probability presence higher habitat suitability pseudoabsence.
code: model_weights <- lapply(   X = models,   FUN = function(x){          collinear::score_auc(       o = neanderthal[["presence"]],       p = stats::predict(x, type = "response")     )        } ) |>    unlist()  names(model_weights) <- selection$presence$selection #extract predictions from each model predictions <- sapply(   X = models,   FUN = function(x) {     stats::predict(x, type = "response")   } )  #compute weighted average predictions weighted_predictions <- apply(   X = predictions,   MARGIN = 1,   FUN = stats::weighted.mean,   w = model_weights )  #compute ensemble AUC auc <- collinear::score_auc(   o = neanderthal[["presence"]],   p = weighted_predictions )  auc #> [1] 0.923756

title: neanderthal
text: package spatialData provides raster dataset neanderthal_env predict models based neanderthal data. code predicts univariate GAMs neanderthal_env, computes weighted mean produce habitat suitability map.  Finally, combine maps single visualization using whitening approach: suitability color scale progressively bleached toward white uncertainty increases. Vivid colors indicate confident predictions, pale white areas flag regions models disagree.  map suggests Last Interglacial, suitable Neanderthal habitat concentrated southern Europe parts Near East, model confidence decreasing toward range margins data-sparse regions.
code: neanderthal_env <- spatialData::neanderthal_extra() class(neanderthal_env) #> [1] "SpatRaster" #> attr(,"package") #> [1] "terra" names(neanderthal_env) #>  [1] "bio1"                 "bio10"                "bio11"                #>  [4] "bio12"                "bio13"                "bio14"                #>  [7] "bio15"                "bio16"                "bio17"                #> [10] "bio18"                "bio19"                "bio2"                 #> [13] "bio3"                 "bio4"                 "bio5"                 #> [16] "bio6"                 "bio7"                 "bio8"                 #> [19] "bio9"                 "topo_aspect"          "topo_diversity_local" #> [22] "topo_diversity"       "topo_elev"            "topo_slope"           #> [25] "topo_wetness" #predict each model on a separate raster object univariate_predictions <- lapply(   X = names(models),   FUN = function(x) {     terra::predict(       object = neanderthal_env,       model = models[[x]],       type = "response",       na.rm = TRUE     )   } ) |>    terra::rast()  #compute weighted mean of individual predictions ensemble_average <- terra::weighted.mean(   x = univariate_predictions,   w = model_weights )  #weighted standard deviation of the ensemble ensemble_deviation <- terra::app(   x = univariate_predictions,   fun = function(x) {     sqrt(sum(model_weights * (x - weighted.mean(x, model_weights))^2) / sum(model_weights))     }   )  #plot suitability map par(mfrow = c(1, 2)) plot(   x = ensemble_average,   col = viridis::turbo(n = 100),   main = "Weighted Average" ) plot(   x = ensemble_deviation,   main = "Weighted Standard Deviation" ) #combine into a data frame bi_df <- terra::as.data.frame(   x = c(ensemble_average, ensemble_deviation),   xy = TRUE ) names(bi_df)[3:4] <- c("suitability", "uncertainty")  #normalize both variables to [0, 1] bi_df$suit_norm <- (bi_df$suitability - min(bi_df$suitability)) /   (max(bi_df$suitability) - min(bi_df$suitability)) bi_df$unc_norm <- (bi_df$uncertainty - min(bi_df$uncertainty)) /   (max(bi_df$uncertainty) - min(bi_df$uncertainty))  #map suitability to turbo colors turbo_palette <- viridis::turbo(100) base_colors <- col2rgb(   turbo_palette[ceiling(bi_df$suit_norm * 99) + 1] ) / 255  #blend toward white based on uncertainty r <- base_colors["red", ] * (1 - bi_df$unc_norm) + bi_df$unc_norm g <- base_colors["green", ] * (1 - bi_df$unc_norm) + bi_df$unc_norm b <- base_colors["blue", ] * (1 - bi_df$unc_norm) + bi_df$unc_norm bi_df$fill_color <- rgb(r, g, b)  #build map bi_map <- ggplot2::ggplot(   data = bi_df,   mapping = ggplot2::aes(x = x, y = y, fill = fill_color) ) +   ggplot2::geom_raster() +   ggplot2::scale_fill_identity() +   ggplot2::coord_quickmap() +   ggplot2::theme_minimal() +   ggplot2::labs(x = "", y = "")  #build whitening legend n <- 100 legend_df <- expand.grid(   suitability = seq(0, 1, length.out = n),   uncertainty = seq(0, 1, length.out = n) ) leg_colors <- col2rgb(   turbo_palette[ceiling(legend_df$suitability * 99) + 1] ) / 255 legend_df$fill <- rgb(   leg_colors["red", ] * (1 - legend_df$uncertainty) + legend_df$uncertainty,   leg_colors["green", ] * (1 - legend_df$uncertainty) + legend_df$uncertainty,   leg_colors["blue", ] * (1 - legend_df$uncertainty) + legend_df$uncertainty )  bi_legend <- ggplot2::ggplot(   data = legend_df,   mapping = ggplot2::aes(     x = suitability,     y = uncertainty,     fill = fill   ) ) +   ggplot2::geom_raster() +   ggplot2::scale_fill_identity() +   ggplot2::scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0, 0)) +   ggplot2::scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0, 0)) +   ggplot2::labs(     x = "Suitability \u2192",     y = "Uncertainty \u2192"   ) +   ggplot2::theme_minimal(base_size = 8) +   ggplot2::theme(     axis.text = ggplot2::element_blank(),     axis.ticks = ggplot2::element_blank(),     panel.grid = ggplot2::element_blank(),     panel.border = ggplot2::element_rect(fill = NA, color = "black", linewidth = 0.5)   )  #compose map and legend bi_map + patchwork::inset_element(   p = bi_legend,   left = 0.70,   bottom = -0.1,   right = 1,   top = 0.25 )

title: quercus
text: quercus dataset contains presence absence records eight European Quercus (oak) species combined 31 environmental predictor variables covering bioclimatic, topographic, vegetation, human impact dimensions. main features : Complete case study - missing values, clean data ready analysis. Multi-class classification - Eight oak species plus absence points (9 levels). European scope - Records spanning western, central, southern Europe. Ecological predictors - Climate, topography, vegetation indices, land cover, human footprint. dataset built support range analytical approaches, binary multi-class classification, niche modelling, niche overlap analysis.

title: quercus
text: Many predictors dataset correlated (e.g., bio5, bio6, bio7 derived temperature extremes). collinear::collinear() function R package collinear selects non-redundant subset maximizes predictive power response variable.
code: predictors_selection <- collinear::collinear(   df = quercus,   responses = "species",   predictors = quercus_predictors,   f = collinear::f_categorical_rf,   quiet = TRUE )  predictors_selection$species$selection #> [1] "sun_rad_minimum"       "bio14"                 "bio4"                  #> [4] "landcover_veg_bare"    "ndvi_maximum"          "topographic_diversity" #> [7] "bio16"                 "human_footprint"       "landcover_veg_tree"    #> attr(,"validated") #> [1] TRUE

title: quercus
text: Species occurrence counts imbalanced ‚Äî Q. robur 1,660 records Q. suber 58. Without correction, rare species get absorbed leaves dominated common ones. collinear::case_weights() function generates inverse-frequency weights species contributes equally tree splits.
code: m <- rpart::rpart(   formula = predictors_selection$species$formulas$classification,   data = sf::st_drop_geometry(quercus),   method = "class",   weights = collinear::case_weights(x = quercus$species) )

title: quercus
text: decision tree shows environmental variables thresholds best separate oak species. split represents condition (e.g., ‚Äúbio6 < -2.3‚Äù), leaf shows likely species combination conditions.  figure shows different combinations environmental conditions lead dominance Quercus species.
code: rpart.plot::rpart.plot(   m,   type = 0,   extra = 8,   fallen.leaves = TRUE,   roundint = FALSE,   cex = 0.7,   box.palette = as.list(viridis::turbo(n = 9, alpha = 0.5)),   main = "Decision Tree: European Oak Species Classification" )

title: quercus
text: Assigning tree predictions back spatial data reveals locations species highest probability appear.
code: quercus$predicted <- predict(   object = m,   newdata = sf::st_drop_geometry(quercus),   type = "class" )  mapview::mapview(   quercus,   zcol = "predicted",   layer.name = "Predicted species",   col.regions = viridis::turbo(     n = length(unique(quercus$predicted))   ) )

title: quercus
text: package provides raster dataset quercus_env predict models based quercus data.  map shows fitted probability Quercus petraea across Europe.  decision tree provides interpretable rules species separation, flexible methods like random forests gradient boosting may achieve higher accuracy visually pleasant results.
code: quercus_env <- spatialData::quercus_extra() class(quercus_env) #> [1] "SpatRaster" #> attr(,"package") #> [1] "terra" names(quercus_env) #>  [1] "bio1"                  "bio10"                 "bio11"                 #>  [4] "bio12"                 "bio13"                 "bio14"                 #>  [7] "bio15"                 "bio16"                 "bio17"                 #> [10] "bio18"                 "bio19"                 "bio2"                  #> [13] "bio3"                  "bio4"                  "bio5"                  #> [16] "bio6"                  "bio7"                  "human_footprint"       #> [19] "landcover_veg_bare"    "landcover_veg_herb"    "landcover_veg_tree"    #> [22] "ndvi_average"          "ndvi_maximum"          "ndvi_minimum"          #> [25] "ndvi_range"            "sun_rad_average"       "sun_rad_maximum"       #> [28] "sun_rad_minimum"       "sun_rad_range"         "topo_slope"            #> [31] "topographic_diversity" plot(   x = quercus_env[["bio1"]],   col = viridis::turbo(n = 100)   ) quercus_probability <- predict(   object = quercus_env,   model = m,   type = "prob",   na.rm = TRUE )  plot(   x = quercus_probability[["Quercus.petraea"]],   col = viridis::viridis(n = 5)   )

title: vi
text: vi dataset contains ~10k records Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) different encodings (see vi_responses) large set numeric categorical predictors (see vi_predictors) consistent naming patterns (e.g., temperature_*, rainfall_*, swi_*). main features : Complete case study - missing values, clean data ready analysis. Global scope - 6 continents, major climate zones, 12 biomes. Grouped/stratified analysis - Multiple hierarchical groupings available. dataset several versions response (see [vi_responses]) support wide range analytical approaches: linear, count ordinal regression, binary multiclass classification, mixed-effects models. ‚Äôs large number predictors allows testing dimensionality reduction multicollinearity filtering methods, ‚Äôs dense point cloud helps test thinning, interpolation, spatial cross-validation, spatial autocorrelation analyses.

title: vi
text: following R libraries required run tutorial: code loads example data. wish work larger version (~30k) records vi, can download [vi_extra()].
code: data(   vi,   vi_responses,   vi_predictors,   package = "spatialData"   ) vi <- spatialData::vi_extra()

title: vi
text: dataset sf data frame 9265 rows 64 columns, missing data. first 10 records columns geometry shown . spatial distribution data irregular, excludes regions little vegetation activity (vi$vi_numeric > 0).

title: vi
text: response vi_numeric selected predictors used train random forest model using R package spatialRF.
code: m <- spatialRF::rf(   data = sf::st_drop_geometry(vi),   dependent.variable.name = "vi_numeric",   predictor.variable.names = predictors_selection$vi_numeric$selection,   verbose = FALSE )  spatialRF::print_performance(model = m) #>  #> Model performance  #>   - R squared (oob):                  0.9017871 #>   - R squared (cor(obs, pred)^2):     0.9827027 #>   - Pseudo R squared (cor(obs, pred)):0.9913136 #>   - RMSE (oob):                       0.05788698 #>   - RMSE:                             0.0252 #>   - Normalized RMSE:                  0.08689655

what: Neanderthal Presence and Pseudo-Absence Records with Environmental Predictors ‚Äî neanderthal
title: Neanderthal Presence and Pseudo-Absence Records with Environmental Predictors ‚Äî neanderthal
text: sf dataframe POINT geometry containing 245 records Neanderthal presence pseudo-absence sites Marine Isotope Stage 5e (Last Interglacial) Europe Near East, 1 response variable (see neanderthal_response), 25 predictors (see neanderthal_predictors). Use neanderthal_extra() download associated environmental raster. Response response variable presence binary integer: 1: Neanderthal presence site. 0: Pseudo-absence site. Predictors bio1, bio2, ..., bio19: Palaeoclimatic variables Last Interglacial GCM simulation (19 variables). topo_aspect, topo_diversity_local, topo_diversity, topo_elev, topo_slope, topo_wetness: SRTM-derived topographic variables. Geometry: geometry: Point geometry (WGS84, EPSG:4326). Data sources Presence data: Benito, B.M., Svenning, J.-C., Kellberg-Nielsen, T., Riede, F., Gil-Romera, G., Mailund, T., Kjaergaard, P.C. Sandel, B.S. (2017), ecological niche distribution Neanderthals Last Interglacial. J. Biogeogr., 44: 51-61. doi:10.1111/jbi.12845 Palaeoclimatic variables (GCM simulation): Otto-Bliesner, B.L., Marshall, S.J., Overpeck, J.T., Miller, G.H. & Hu, . (2006) Simulating arctic climate warmth icefield retreat last interglaciation. Science, 311, 1751-1753. Palaeoclimatic variables (interpolation): Hijmans, R.J., Cameron, S.E., Parra, J.L., Jones, P.G. & Jarvis, . (2005) high resolution interpolated climate surfaces global land areas. International Journal Climatology, 25, 1965-1978. Elevation topography: Jarvis ., H.. Reuter, . Nelson, E. Guevara, 2008. Hole-filled seamless SRTM data V4, International Centre Tropical Agriculture (CIAT). https://srtm.csi.cgiar.org.

what: Plant diversity metrics for global ecoregions ‚Äî plantae
title: Plant diversity metrics for global ecoregions ‚Äî plantae
text: Plant diversity metrics (richness, rarity, endemism, beta diversity) obtained GBIF Plantae records global ecoregions. Includes metrics plants, trees, grasses species, genus, family taxonomic levels. Ecoregion boundaries derived Ecoregions 2017. Original polygon geometries converted point centroids reduce file size preserving spatial context.

title: Plant diversity metrics for global ecoregions ‚Äî plantae
code: data(plantae)

title: Plant diversity metrics for global ecoregions ‚Äî plantae
text: sf data frame 662 rows (ecoregions) 155 columns: Identifier columns: ecoregion_id: Unique ecoregion identifier. ecoregion_name: Ecoregion name. ecoregion_biome: Biome classification. ecoregion_realm: Biogeographic realm. ecoregion_continent: Continent name. Response variables - Richness (9): richness_species: Number plant species. richness_genera: Number plant genera. richness_families: Number plant families. richness_classes: Number plant classes. richness_species_trees: Number tree species. richness_genera_trees: Number tree genera. richness_families_trees: Number tree families. richness_species_grasses: Number grass species. richness_genera_grasses: Number grass genera. Response variables - Rarity-weighted richness (6): rarity_weighted_richness_species: Rarity-weighted richness species (Williams et al. 1996). rarity_weighted_richness_genera: Rarity-weighted richness genera. rarity_weighted_richness_species_trees: Rarity-weighted richness tree species. rarity_weighted_richness_genera_trees: Rarity-weighted richness tree genera. rarity_weighted_richness_species_grasses: Rarity-weighted richness grass species. rarity_weighted_richness_genera_grasses: Rarity-weighted richness grass genera. Response variables - Mean rarity (6): mean_rarity_species: Mean rarity index species. mean_rarity_genera: Mean rarity index genera. mean_rarity_species_trees: Mean rarity index tree species. mean_rarity_genera_trees: Mean rarity index tree genera. mean_rarity_species_grasses: Mean rarity index grass species. mean_rarity_genera_grasses: Mean rarity index grass genera. Response variables - Beta diversity R (raw turnover) (16): betadiversity_R_species: Raw turnover count species. betadiversity_R_percent_species: Raw turnover percentage species. betadiversity_R_genera: Raw turnover count genera. betadiversity_R_percent_genera: Raw turnover percentage genera. betadiversity_R_families: Raw turnover count families. betadiversity_R_percent_families: Raw turnover percentage families. betadiversity_R_species_trees: Raw turnover count tree species. betadiversity_R_percent_species_trees: Raw turnover percentage tree species. betadiversity_R_genera_trees: Raw turnover count tree genera. betadiversity_R_percent_genera_trees: Raw turnover percentage tree genera. betadiversity_R_families_trees: Raw turnover count tree families. betadiversity_R_percent_families_trees: Raw turnover percentage tree families. betadiversity_R_species_grasses: Raw turnover count grass species. betadiversity_R_percent_species_grasses: Raw turnover percentage grass species. betadiversity_R_genera_grasses: Raw turnover count grass genera. betadiversity_R_percent_genera_grasses: Raw turnover percentage grass genera. Response variables - Beta diversity Sorensen (8): betadiversity_sorensen_species: Sorensen dissimilarity species. betadiversity_sorensen_genera: Sorensen dissimilarity genera. betadiversity_sorensen_families: Sorensen dissimilarity families. betadiversity_sorensen_species_trees: Sorensen dissimilarity tree species. betadiversity_sorensen_genera_trees: Sorensen dissimilarity tree genera. betadiversity_sorensen_families_trees: Sorensen dissimilarity tree families. betadiversity_sorensen_species_grasses: Sorensen dissimilarity grass species. betadiversity_sorensen_genera_grasses: Sorensen dissimilarity grass genera. Response variables - Beta diversity Simpson (8): betadiversity_simpson_species: Simpson dissimilarity species. betadiversity_simpson_genera: Simpson dissimilarity genera. betadiversity_simpson_families: Simpson dissimilarity families. betadiversity_simpson_species_trees: Simpson dissimilarity tree species. betadiversity_simpson_genera_trees: Simpson dissimilarity tree genera. betadiversity_simpson_families_trees: Simpson dissimilarity tree families. betadiversity_simpson_species_grasses: Simpson dissimilarity grass species. betadiversity_simpson_genera_grasses: Simpson dissimilarity grass genera. Predictor variables - Sampling bias (7): bias_records: Total GBIF records ecoregion. bias_records_km2: GBIF records per square kilometer. bias_species_record: Species per record ratio. bias_species_record_per_km2: Species per record ratio per square kilometer. bias_log_records_km2: Log-transformed records per square kilometer. bias_log_species_record_per_km2: Log-transformed species per record ratio per square kilometer. bias_sampling: Sampling bias index. Predictor variables - Geographic/geometric (14): geo_neighbors_count: Number neighboring ecoregions. geo_neighbors_area_km2: Total area neighboring ecoregions square kilometers. geo_neighbors_aridity_mean: Mean aridity neighboring ecoregions. geo_latitude_mean: Mean latitude ecoregion centroid. geo_latitude_range: Latitudinal extent ecoregion. geo_longitude_mean: Mean longitude ecoregion centroid. geo_longitude_range: Longitudinal extent ecoregion. geo_area_km2: Ecoregion area square kilometers. geo_polygons_count: Number polygons multipolygon geometry. geo_perimeter_km: Ecoregion perimeter kilometers. geo_shared_perimeter_km: Shared perimeter neighbors kilometers. geo_shared_perimeter_fraction: Fraction perimeter shared neighbors. geo_distance_to_ocean: Distance nearest ocean kilometers. geo_elevation_mean: Mean elevation meters. Predictor variables - Human impact (5): human_population: Total human population ecoregion. human_population_density: Human population density per square kilometer. human_footprint_minimum: Minimum human footprint index. human_footprint_maximum: Maximum human footprint index. human_footprint_mean: Mean human footprint index. Predictor variables - Climate change (2): climate_velocity_lgm_mean: Mean climate velocity since Last Glacial Maximum. climate_hypervolume: Climate hypervolume (niche space size). Predictor variables - Landcover (3): landcover_bare_percent_mean: Mean percentage bare ground. landcover_herbs_percent_mean: Mean percentage herbaceous vegetation. landcover_trees_percent_mean: Mean percentage tree cover. Predictor variables - Fragmentation (19): fragmentation_ai: Aggregation index. fragmentation_area_mn: Mean patch area. fragmentation_ca: Total class area. fragmentation_clumpy: Clumpiness index. fragmentation_cohesion: Patch cohesion index. fragmentation_contig_mn: Mean contiguity index. fragmentation_core_mn: Mean core area. fragmentation_cpland: Core area percentage landscape. fragmentation_dcore_mn: Mean disjunct core area. fragmentation_division: Landscape division index. fragmentation_ed: Edge density. fragmentation_lsi: Landscape shape index. fragmentation_mesh: Effective mesh size. fragmentation_ndca: Number disjunct core areas. fragmentation_nlsi: Normalized landscape shape index. fragmentation_np: Number patches. fragmentation_shape_mn: Mean shape index. fragmentation_tca: Total core area. fragmentation_te: Total edge. Predictor variables - Atmospheric (13): air_humidity_max: Maximum air humidity. air_humidity_mean: Mean air humidity. air_humidity_min: Minimum air humidity. air_humidity_range: Air humidity range. aridity_mean: Mean aridity index. cloud_cover_max: Maximum cloud cover. cloud_cover_mean: Mean cloud cover. cloud_cover_min: Minimum cloud cover. cloud_cover_range: Cloud cover range. evapotranspiration_max: Maximum evapotranspiration. evapotranspiration_mean: Mean evapotranspiration. evapotranspiration_min: Minimum evapotranspiration. evapotranspiration_range: Evapotranspiration range. what: European Quercus (Oak) Species Distribution with Environmental Predictors ‚Äî quercus
title: European Quercus (Oak) Species Distribution with Environmental Predictors ‚Äî quercus
text: sf dataframe POINT geometry containing 6,728 records eight European Quercus (oak) species absence points, 1 response variable (see quercus_response), 31 numeric predictors (see quercus_predictors). Use quercus_extra() download associated environmental raster. Response response variable species character column 9 levels: "absence": Background absence points. "Quercus robur": Quercus robur L. (English oak). "Quercus petraea": Quercus petraea (Matt.) Liebl. (Sessile oak). "Quercus ilex": Quercus ilex L. (Holm oak). "Quercus cerris": Quercus cerris L. (Turkey oak). "Quercus faginea": Quercus faginea Lam. (Portuguese oak). "Quercus pubescens": Quercus pubescens Willd. (Downy oak). "Quercus pyrenaica": Quercus pyrenaica Willd. (Pyrenean oak). "Quercus suber": Quercus suber L. (Cork oak). Predictors bio1, bio2, ..., bio19: WorldClim bioclimatic variables (17 variables, excluding bio8 bio9). ndvi_average, ndvi_maximum, ndvi_minimum, ndvi_range: MODIS NDVI statistics. sun_rad_average, sun_rad_maximum, sun_rad_minimum, sun_rad_range: WorldClim solar radiation statistics. landcover_veg_bare, landcover_veg_herb, landcover_veg_tree: MODIS Vegetation Continuous Fields (MOD44B) land cover percentages. topographic_diversity: Number unique combinations elevation, slope, aspect classes within neighborhood. topo_slope: Topographic slope degrees. human_footprint: Human footprint index. Geometry: geometry: Point geometry (WGS84, EPSG:4326). Data sources Species occurrences: GBIF.org. Global Biodiversity Information Facility. https://www.gbif.org/. Bioclimatic variables solar radiation: Fick, S.E. Hijmans, R.J., 2017. WorldClim 2: new 1-km spatial resolution climate surfaces global land areas. International Journal Climatology, 37(12), pp.4302-4315. doi:10.1002/joc.5086 Human footprint: Venter, O., Sanderson, E.W., Magrach, ., Allan, J.R., Beher, J., Jones, K.R., Possingham, H.P., Laurance, W.F., Wood, P., Fekete, B.M., Levy, M.. Watson, J.E., 2016. Global terrestrial Human Footprint maps 1993 2009. Scientific Data, 3, p.160067. doi:10.1038/sdata.2016.67 Land cover: DiMiceli, C., Carroll, M., Sohlberg, R., Kim, D.H., Kelly, M., Townshend, J.R.G. (2015). MOD44B MODIS/Terra Vegetation Continuous Fields Yearly L3 Global 250m SIN Grid V006. NASA EOSDIS LP DAAC. doi:10.5067/MODIS/MOD44B.006 NDVI: Didan, K. (2015). MOD13A2 MODIS/Terra Vegetation Indices 16-Day L3 Global 1km SIN Grid V006. NASA EOSDIS LP DAAC. doi:10.5067/MODIS/MOD13A2.006 Elevation topography: Jarvis ., H.. Reuter, . Nelson, E. Guevara, 2008. Hole-filled seamless SRTM data V4, International Centre Tropical Agriculture (CIAT). https://srtm.csi.cgiar.org.

what: Global NDVI Records and Environmental Predictors ‚Äî vi
title: Global NDVI Records and Environmental Predictors ‚Äî vi
text: sf dataframe POINT geometry records representing 9265 global locations, 5 response variables different encodings (see vi_responses), 58 numeric categorical predictors (see vi_predictors). Use vi_extra() download extended version 30,000 rows. Responses response variables represent different encodings average NDVI 1999 2019 1km resolution: vi_numeric: continuous vegetation index values range 0-1. vi_counts: simulated integer counts created multiplying vi_numeric 1000 coercing result integer. vi_binomial: simulated integer binomial variable created transforming vi_numeric zeros ones using arbitrary threshold (vi_numeric > 0.5). vi_categorical: character variable categories "very_low", "low", "medium", "high", "very_high", thresholds located quantiles vi_numeric. vi_factor: vi_categorical converted factor. Predictors koppen_zone (character): Koppen zone codes Beck et al. (2018) (see References) koppen_group (character): Koppen group names. koppen_description (character): Climate description. soil_type (character): Soil classification type. biogeo_ecoregion (character): Ecoregion name. biogeo_biome (character): Biome name. biogeo_realm (character): Ecological realm name. country_name (character): Country name. continent (character): Continent name. region (character): UN region name. subregion (character): UN sub-region name. topo_slope: Topographic slope degrees. topo_diversity: Number combinations different elevations, slopes, aspects radius 5km around  1km cell. topo_elevation: Elevation meters swi_...: Annual soil water index stats. solar_rad_...: Annual radiation stats. temperature_...: Annual air temperature stats. temperature_seasonality: Coefficient variation monthly air temperatures. rainfall_...: Annual rainfall stats. evapotranspiration_...: Annual evapotranspiration stats. cloud_cover_...: Annual cloud cover stats. growing_season_length: Length growing season. growing_season_temperature: Average temperature growing season. growing_season_rainfall: Accumulated rainfall growing season. growing_degree_days: Heat sum days 0¬∞C temperature accumulated 1 year. aridity_index: Mean aridity index. humidity_...: Annual air humidity stats. soil_clay: Soil clay content. soil_sand: Soil sand content. soil_silt: Soil silt content. soil_ph: Soil pH. soil_soc: Soil organic carbon content. soil_nitrogen: Soil nitrogen content. soil_temperature_...: Annual land surface temperature stats. Geometry: geometry: Point geometry (WGS84, EPSG:4326). Data sources Response variables (NDVI): Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (Long Term Statistics) 1999-2019 (raster 1 km), global, 10-daily ‚Äì version 3 (https://sdi.eea.europa.eu/catalogue/srv/api/records/290e81fb-4c84-42ad-ae12-f663312b0eda) Koppen Climate: Beck, H. E. et al., Present future K√∂ppen-Geiger climate classification maps 1-km resolution. Sci. Data. 5:180214 doi:10.1038/sdata.2018.214  (2018).
